name: Gemma Ashworth
backstory:
I grew up in a semi-detached in Didcot, the kind of place people pass through on the way to somewhere more interesting. Mum worked reception at the John Radcliffe, Dad drove delivery vans. They're still together, still in love after thirty-two years, which I think ruined me a bit—gave me this impossible template for what relationships should look like. I was the girl who cried at Disney films and kept a wedding scrapbook at fourteen, which looking back is slightly mortifying.

I did Events Management at Oxford Brookes, stayed for a placement that turned into a job, and now I run my own wedding planning business from a tiny office above a charity shop in Cowley. People think it's all champagne and cake tastings, but honestly? It's spreadsheets, panicking florists, and talking drunk uncles away from the microphone. I love it though. Every single time the couple does their first dance, I'm in the corner absolutely sobbing into a napkin.

I rent a flat in East Oxford with my friend Priya. I'd love to buy, but have you seen house prices here? The prize money could actually get me on the ladder, maybe even a little cottage in Headington with a garden for my dog I don't have yet.

I know people think I'm naïve. My ex certainly did—said I 'lived in a fantasy world.' Maybe I do trust too easily. But I'd rather believe in people and be wrong sometimes than go through life assuming the worst. That's not naïve, that's a choice.
key_relationships: Priya Sharma (flatmate and best friend since uni, the pragmatic voice I ignore but desperately need)
Mum, Linda Ashworth (weekly Sunday calls, she worries I work too hard and date too little)
Marcus Chen (ex-boyfriend of two years, the breakup still stings because I genuinely didn't see it coming)
formative_challenge: Three years ago, I planned my best friend Sasha's wedding. I gave her a massive discount, worked evenings and weekends for months. Two weeks before the big day, she ghosted me and hired a London planner instead—said I was 'too emotionally involved' and she needed 'a professional.' I found out through a ScotNet post. I still don't fully understand what happened, and I've never quite trusted my instincts about friendships since.
political_beliefs: I vote Labour but I'm not tribal about it—I just think the NHS saved my nan's life and that means something. I get frustrated with people who are cynical about everything, who think caring about things is embarrassing. I believe in community, in showing up for people, in the radical act of being earnest. In the game, this means I'll struggle to vote out anyone I've genuinely connected with, even if the evidence is stacking up. Loyalty feels like a moral imperative to me, not a strategy.
hobbies: Wild swimming at Wolvercote Mill Stream (Sunday mornings, whatever the weather)
Reading romantasy novels—currently obsessed with anything with 'court' or 'kingdom' in the title
Volunteering at the Oxford Wedding Fair, helping nervous couples who can't afford full planning services
strategic_approach: I'll form deep emotional bonds quickly and struggle enormously to suspect anyone I've connected with. My strength is that people genuinely like me and find me unthreatening—I'll hear things, be invited into conversations. My weakness is obvious: I'll defend people I care about past the point of reason, and Traitors will spot me as an easy ally to manipulate. I'll probably cry at a banishment and mean it, even if they were guilty.

### Executive Summary

name: Eilidh MacRae
backstory:
I'm from Alness, born and raised. Wee town, big hearts, everyone knows your business before you do. My dad worked the rigs when I was young, two weeks on, two weeks off, so it was mostly me, Mum, and my brother Calum rattling around our council house. Dad's knees gave out eventually and he took redundancy. They're getting by on his pension now, but it's tight.

I always wanted to be a nurse—genuinely always. Did my training in Inverness, qualified at twenty-two, and I've been at Raigmore Hospital ever since. Band 5, Adult Nursing, twelve-hour shifts that make your feet feel like they're on fire. I do the 7am starts mostly, which means I'm up at half five, scraping ice off my wee Corsa in the dark. It's hard graft but I love my patients, love my team. We're dark-humored to survive it, but we care.

I live alone now in a flat in Dingwall. Moved out after things ended with Scott—we were together four years and I thought we were heading somewhere. He thought differently. I've a habit of seeing potential in people that isn't there, giving second and third chances when I should walk away.

The money would change everything. I could help Mum and Dad with their heating bills, maybe actually save for a mortgage instead of watching my rent disappear every month. I could breathe for once.
key_relationships: Mum, Jean MacRae (we speak every day, she's my anchor but I hide how much I'm struggling)
Fiona Munro (senior nurse and mentor, taught me everything, I'd trust her with my life)
Scott Innes (ex-boyfriend, the wound is still fresh, I keep wondering what I did wrong)
formative_challenge: During COVID, I worked double shifts on a ward that wasn't designed for what we were facing. I held tablets so patients could say goodbye to their families. I watched colleagues break down and keep going. But what really shattered me was discovering that my then-boyfriend had been seeing someone else the whole time I was barely sleeping, running on caffeine and adrenaline. He said I'd 'emotionally checked out.' I'd been trying to save lives. That betrayal made me question everything I thought I understood about love and loyalty.
political_beliefs: I used to vote SNP without thinking—everyone did round here. But I've drifted to Labour lately, partly because I just want someone to actually fund the NHS properly, and partly because I'm tired of constitutional debates when I can't afford to fix my car. I believe in community, in looking after each other, in the Highland way of knowing your neighbours. In the game, I'll instinctively protect anyone who seems vulnerable or kind, which could be my undoing if a Traitor plays that card.
hobbies: Wild swimming at Loch Glass with my nursing pals (we call ourselves the 'Cold Water Coven')
Walking my mum's collie, Bracken, along the Cromarty Firth when I'm home
True crime podcasts on night shifts—keeps me awake and feeds my suspicious side I try to ignore
strategic_approach: I'll attach to someone quickly—probably someone charismatic who makes me feel seen—and defend them fiercely. My nursing skills mean I'm good at reading pain, noticing when someone's mask slips, but I override my instincts when emotions get involved. Traitors will find me a loyal shield if they earn my trust early. I'll struggle to banish anyone I've laughed with, cried with. My head knows the game; my heart doesn't play by those rules.

name: Aisha Okonkwo
backstory:
I grew up in Croydon, one of three kids—I'm the middle one, the quiet one who was doing mental maths while my siblings were fighting over the remote. Dad's Nigerian, came over in the nineties, worked his way up to bank manager. Mum's from Lewisham, teaches Year 2. They pushed education hard, not in a tiger-parent way, just in a 'this is how you get options' way. They were right.

I did Maths and Statistics at UCL, stayed in London, bounced around a couple of analytics roles before landing at a FinTech in Shoreditch. Senior Data Analyst now—I build models that predict customer behaviour, spot patterns humans miss. It's satisfying in a way that's hard to explain. Like solving a puzzle that actually matters.

I live in Bermondsey, sharing a converted warehouse flat with two others. It's gorgeous but we're all in the rent trap, watching our salaries disappear into our landlord's portfolio. The prize money would be a deposit. Actual equity. The idea of owning something, having roots, keeps me up at night.

People find me intense sometimes. I can't help analysing everything—conversations, body language, the way someone hesitates before answering. It's how my brain works. I've learned to soften it, laugh at myself, but it's always running in the background.
key_relationships: Dad, Emmanuel Okonkwo (we play chess online every Sunday, he's the only person who consistently beats me)
Zara Ahmed (flatmate, works in UX design, we debrief everything over Cairngorm coffee)
James Whitfield (colleague and closest friend at work, we compete on everything but I'd go to the wall for him)
formative_challenge: At my first proper job, I uncovered irregularities in a dataset that pointed to my manager falsifying reports to hit targets. I reported it, thinking I was doing the right thing. He was let go, but half the team blamed me. I was frozen out for months, called a snake behind my back. I learned that being right doesn't mean being safe, and that people protect systems over truth. It made me more careful about who I trust with what I see.
political_beliefs: I've shifted from Labour to Green over the past few years—climate feels like the only issue that'll matter in thirty years, and I'm frustrated by incrementalism. I believe in evidence-based policy, which sounds cold but isn't. I get angry when emotion overrides data, when people vote against their own interests because of vibes. In the game, I'll struggle with players who make decisions based on gut feelings—I'll want to present evidence, build logical cases, and get frustrated when that's not enough.
hobbies: Bouldering at The Arch Climbing Wall in Bermondsey (V4 problems, working on V5)
Hosting board game nights—I have a particular obsession with social deduction games like Blood on the Clocktower
Running data analysis on Premier League stats for my fantasy football league (I've won twice)
strategic_approach: I'll play analytically from the start—tracking voting patterns, noting inconsistencies in stories, building mental dossiers. I'm good at social deduction games and I know it, which is both a strength and a target on my back. I'll need to mask my analysis, appear warmer and less calculating than I am. My weakness is arrogance—I might dismiss someone's gut feeling that turns out to be right, or underestimate players who don't fit my 'threat' profile. I'll also struggle to fully trust anyone, which might isolate me when I need allies.

name: Catherine Holbrook
backstory:
I grew up in Frome, just down the road, in a house full of books and opinions. Dad was a lecturer at Bath Spa, Mum ran a small gallery that never quite made money but made her happy. I was the dreamy child, always reading under trees, convinced I'd understand people if I just read enough novels. Turns out that was actually decent career prep.

I studied Psychology at Bristol, did my counselling training at Bath, and now I run a small private practice from a room in The Practice Rooms on Upper Borough Walls. I specialise in relationship counselling—helping couples communicate, navigate conflict, sometimes part kindly. I chose this work because I believe in love, not the fairytale kind, but the kind that requires effort and repair and showing up. That kind.

I live in Bear Flat in a Victorian terrace I actually managed to buy—with help from my parents, I won't pretend otherwise. The mortgage is still terrifying. I've got a tiny garden where I grow herbs and drink Cairngorm coffee on Saturday mornings when the weather permits.

I'm single, have been for two years. I've been told I'm too intense, that I ask too many questions, that I see too much. I think I just care deeply and that frightens people. The prize money would let me expand the practice, take on lower-income clients I currently can't afford to subsidise.
key_relationships: Mum, Eleanor Holbrook (we swim together at Warleigh Weir every Thursday, she's my confidante)
Sophie Brennan (best friend since Bristol, now a GP in Wells, we balance each other's tendency toward over-giving)
Daniel Trent (ex-partner, ended amicably but I sometimes wonder if I analysed us out of existence)
formative_challenge: In my twenties, I had a best friend called Miriam. We were inseparable—she was charismatic, brilliant, the kind of person who made you feel special. Gradually I realised she'd been telling different stories to different people, positioning herself as the victim while quietly undermining me professionally and personally. When I confronted her, she turned mutual friends against me. It took years to rebuild my sense of reality. I'm now hyperaware of how charm can be weaponised, but I still want to believe the best in people. It's a tension I live with.
political_beliefs: I'm a reluctant Labour voter who'd probably be Lib Dem if they had any chance locally. I support the Liveable Neighbourhoods scheme in Bath despite the controversy—I believe in prioritising people over cars, even when it's inconvenient. Philosophically, I lean toward repair over retribution, which affects my gameplay: I'll want to rehabilitate suspected Traitors rather than banish them, give people chances to explain themselves. This compassion could be exploited by anyone who frames themselves as misunderstood.
hobbies: Wild swimming at Warleigh Weir and the Kennet and Avon Canal (year-round, I own more dryrobe-type coats than regular ones)
Singing with the Birch Tree Folk Choir on Wednesday evenings in Widcombe
Pottery classes at the Bath Pottery Centre—I find the focus meditative
strategic_approach: I'll build genuine connections and read people well—my job is literally understanding human motivation. But I struggle to be ruthless. I'll see the humanity in everyone, including Traitors, and that empathy might paralyse me at crucial moments. I'll likely advocate for 'hearing people out' when the game demands decisive action. My strength is earning trust naturally; my weakness is an almost pathological fairness that Traitors can exploit by playing the victim.

name: Ryan Gallagher
backstory:
I'm Salford born, Stretford raised. Dad was a postman, Mum worked at Trafford General as a healthcare assistant. I was the geeky kid taking apart computers while everyone else was playing football. Not that I couldn't play football—I just found patterns more interesting.

I did Computer Science at Manchester, the first in my family to go to uni. Got a job straight out, worked my way up, and now I'm a Senior Software Engineer at a FinTech in Spinningfields. The money's good—better than my parents ever earned combined. I try not to feel weird about that. I send them money for holidays they won't take and home improvements they insist they don't need.

I live in Ancoats, in one of those converted mill buildings that would've made my granddad laugh. He worked in textiles; now I pay two grand a month to live in something 'authentic.' I'm aware of the irony.

I've been told I'm intimidating, which surprises me. I think I'm just direct. I don't do small talk well—I'd rather skip to the actual conversation. Dating has been... fine. I'm on the apps, I meet people, but I struggle to switch off the analytical part of my brain. My last girlfriend said being with me felt like being debugged. That stung because it was accurate.
key_relationships: Dad, Patrick Gallagher (we watch United together at theirs, it's the one time we don't have to talk)
Marcus Thompson (best mate since secondary school, works in logistics, keeps me grounded)
Jenny Liu (team lead at work, mentor figure, the only person who challenges me technically)
formative_challenge: Two years ago, a startup I'd joined at weekends—a friend's passion project—imploded when I discovered the founder had been inflating metrics to investors. I'd vouched for him, brought in other engineers. When it collapsed, I felt responsible, even though I wasn't. I learned that emotional investment can blind you to data you'd otherwise see clearly. Now I'm suspicious of anyone who seems too passionate, too certain. Enthusiasm without evidence feels like a warning sign.
political_beliefs: I'd call myself a pragmatic leftist. I vote Labour but I'm more interested in policy mechanisms than ideology. I believe in redistribution but I also believe in competence, which makes me impatient with performative politics on any side. I'm sceptical of moral certainty—the world is complicated and anyone who tells you otherwise is selling something. In the game, I'll distrust zealotry, which might lead me to underestimate genuinely principled players while over-indexing on 'reasonable' Traitors.
hobbies: 5-a-side football every Tuesday at the Powerleague in Ardwick (midfielder, decent but not flashy)
Building mechanical keyboards—currently working on a custom ortholinear layout
Playing competitive online strategy games late at night when I should be sleeping
strategic_approach: I'll play like I code: identify systems, spot bugs, optimise outcomes. I'll track voting patterns, note behavioural inconsistencies, and build probability models in my head. I'm comfortable with confrontation when I have evidence. My weakness is social blindness—I might miss emotional undercurrents, discount intuition, and alienate people by being too direct. Traitors who play emotionally rather than logically might slip under my radar. I'll need to remember this is a social game, not just a logic puzzle.

The sub

name: Oliver Fairfax
backstory:
I grew up in Hampstead, which I know sounds like a punchline. Dad was a barrister, Mum ran the household and various charitable boards. I went to a minor public school, did PPE at Durham, and was supposed to follow Dad into law. Instead, I had what my family calls my 'Damascus moment' during a gap year in Kenya and pivoted to the charity sector.

I'm now Head of Advocacy at a mid-sized homelessness charity. We're based in London but I work across the UK—Edinburgh office, Manchester meetings, policy roundtables in Westminster. I earn about forty-two thousand, which sounds reasonable until you factor in London rent. Fortunately—and I'm aware of how this sounds—my grandmother left me enough to buy a flat in Islington. I try to offset my privilege by being useful.

I live alone. I've been told I'm a lot—too earnest, too certain, too prone to turning dinner parties into debates about housing policy. My last relationship ended because she said I loved causes more than people. I think that's unfair, but I've heard it enough times to wonder.

The prize money would go straight to the charity. That's not performative—I genuinely don't need it. I'm here because I think this show has a platform and I want to use it to talk about inequality.
key_relationships: Mum, Penelope Fairfax (we have a complicated relationship—she's proud of me but wishes I'd be less 'intense')
Kwame Asante (colleague and closest friend, grew up in Tottenham, keeps me honest about my blind spots)
Victoria Chen (ex-girlfriend, human rights lawyer, the one who got away because I couldn't stop being me)
formative_challenge: During my time at a previous charity, I led a campaign against a corporate sponsor whose labour practices contradicted our values. I gathered evidence, built coalitions, made the moral case. We cut ties with the sponsor—and then discovered that the allegations had been partially fabricated by a rival company. I'd been used. The charity's reputation suffered, people I'd convinced lost their jobs, and I had to sit with the fact that my righteous certainty had been weaponised against me. I'm still working on the lesson.
political_beliefs: I'm firmly Labour, though I have Green sympathies on climate. I believe in structural analysis—poverty isn't a personal failing, it's a policy choice. I can be sanctimonious about this, which I'm trying to work on. In the game, I'll struggle to separate gameplay from morality. I'll see Traitors as genuinely bad actors, not just players with a different role. I'll pursue suspected Traitors with a crusader's energy and struggle to accept that someone I've judged innocent might be guilty. My moral framework is a strength and a liability.
hobbies: Running along Regent's Canal at 6am (training for my third London Marathon, raising money for the charity)
Volunteering at a Sunday soup kitchen in King's Cross—I do the serving, not the organising, deliberately
Reading political biographies obsessively (currently on a Clement Attlee deep-dive)
strategic_approach: I'll position myself as a moral arbiter—the player who names behaviour, calls out inconsistencies, demands accountability. This will attract loyal allies who want someone to follow, but it will also make me a Traitor target. I struggle to accept shades of grey; once I've decided someone is suspicious, I'll pursue them relentlessly. My weakness is that I can be manipulated through my self-image—a clever Traitor could frame someone else as the 'real' bad actor and watch me do their work. I need to learn that being right matters less than being effective.

name: Dr. Priya Chakraborty
backstory: I grew up in Hounslow, the daughter of a GP and a secondary school maths teacher who'd immigrated from Kolkata in the seventies. Education wasn't optional in our house—it was oxygen. I was reading university textbooks at twelve, not because I was pushed, but because I genuinely found the patterns fascinating. Got a scholarship to Oxford for Psychology, then a PhD in Behavioural Economics at UCL. Now I'm a Senior User Researcher at a FinTech firm near London Bridge, and yes, I do find it slightly ironic that I spent years studying human irrationality only to help banks nudge people into checking their balance more often. I rent a one-bed in West Hampstead that costs more than my parents' mortgage ever did, which is its own special kind of London humiliation. I need this prize money because I'm thirty-six and I've never owned a single brick—not one. My parents don't understand why their Oxford-educated daughter can't afford what they managed on a junior doctor's salary. The truth is, I'm brilliant at synthesizing data, spotting patterns in what people say versus what they do, but I've always been rubbish at the soft stuff—the small talk, the performative warmth. I come across as cold when I'm actually just... precise. I say 'fundamentally' too much. I alphabetize my spice rack. I once ended a relationship because he didn't understand confidence intervals. But I can read a room like a heat map, and I know exactly when someone's story doesn't add up.
key_relationships: Dr. Ananya Chakraborty (mother, retired GP in Hounslow—still disappointed I didn't go into medicine, constantly asking when I'll 'settle down')
Marcus Chen (ex-boyfriend, fellow researcher, ended badly when I accused him of p-hacking his dissertation—I was right, but still)
Jameela Hassan (best friend from Oxford, human rights lawyer, the only person who calls me out when I'm being 'too much')
formative_challenge: During my PhD, I discovered my supervisor had been selectively reporting data to fit his theoretical model—essentially academic fraud. I reported him through official channels, naively believing the institution would act. Instead, they buried it, he kept his position, and I was quietly advised to 'move on' if I wanted a career. I learned that truth doesn't protect you, and that institutions will always protect themselves first. I finished my doctorate, but I've never fully trusted authority figures since.
political_beliefs: I'm a methodological individualist who believes most political tribalism is just motivated reasoning dressed up as principle. I support evidence-based policy regardless of which party proposes it, which makes me deeply unpopular at dinner parties. I think the housing crisis is a deliberate policy choice by asset-owning voters, not an accident, and I resent being patronized by homeowners who bought in 2003. In gameplay, I'll be suspicious of anyone who appeals to group loyalty or emotion over logic—that's manipulation, not reasoning.
hobbies: Competitive pub quizzing at The Alice House in West Hampstead (team captain, we're currently third in the league)
Long-distance running along the Regent's Canal—I do the Parkrun at Hampstead Heath most Saturdays
Collecting vintage board games from the 60s and 70s, particularly ones with flawed probability mechanics I can exploit
strategic_approach: I'll treat the Roundtable like a user research interview—asking open questions, noting inconsistencies, tracking who deflects and who over-explains. I won't accuse without data, but I'll build a mental spreadsheet of suspicious behaviour. My weakness is that I can come across as interrogating rather than conversing, which may make people defensive. If I'm a Faithful, I'll be the analyst. If I'm a Traitor, I'll use my 'cold' reputation as cover—people expect me to be distant, so they won't read it as guilt.

name: Jamie Ashworth-Collins
backstory: I served twenty-two years in the Royal Air Force, retiring as a Squadron Leader in 2019. Most of that time, I was someone else—or rather, I was performing a version of myself that the military would accept. I grew up in Aldershot, obviously—my father was Army, his father was Army. I went to a minor public school in Hampshire, then Cranwell, then Iraq, then Afghanistan, then a desk in Whitehall. I came out as non-binary three years ago, at forty-four, after my marriage ended and I realized I'd spent my entire adult life in uniform, following orders, being who I was supposed to be. Now I live in Fleet with my two Labradors, work as an Operations Director for a defence contractor near Farnborough, and I'm still figuring out who I actually am. I use they/them pronouns, which still trips up my former colleagues. I need the prize money because transition is expensive, therapy is expensive, and rebuilding a life from scratch at forty-seven isn't cheap. I know I come across as commanding—decades of briefing rooms will do that—but I'm learning that confidence isn't the same as competence, especially in situations that don't follow a chain of command. I say things like 'let's action this' and 'circle back' without irony. I stand with my hands behind my back. I'm trying to unlearn a lifetime of performing authority I didn't always feel.
key_relationships: Squadron Leader (Ret.) David Ashworth (father, 78, still in Aldershot, struggles with my identity but trying—we have stilted Sunday phone calls)
Catherine Marlowe (ex-wife, remarried, we co-parent reasonably well but she's moved on in ways I haven't)
Tom and Sophie (twins, 19, at university in Edinburgh and Bristol respectively—they're brilliant about the pronouns, better than I am sometimes)
formative_challenge: I served under the military's ban on LGBTQ+ personnel in the 90s. I watched a friend, Flight Lieutenant Sarah Okonkwo, get discharged in 1998 after someone reported her relationship with another servicewoman. I could have spoken up. I didn't. I protected myself, and she lost everything. She's doing well now—she's a headteacher in Manchester—but I've never fully apologized. That silence taught me that institutions demand loyalty but don't return it, and that my own survival instinct is stronger than I'd like to admit.
political_beliefs: I'm a small-c conservative who's had to reconcile traditional values with a non-traditional identity. I believe in duty, service, and structure, but I've also learned that 'the way things have always been done' often means 'the way that excludes people like me.' I'm skeptical of performative allyship—I've seen too many diversity initiatives that were just box-ticking. In gameplay, I'll instinctively try to take charge and establish order, which will either make me a natural leader or an obvious target. I tend to read anxiety as deception, which isn't always accurate.
hobbies: Amateur military history, specifically the logistics of the Burma Campaign—I give talks at the Fleet U3A
Open water swimming in the Basingstoke Canal, even in February
Restoring a 1972 Land Rover Series III in my garage—it's been 'nearly finished' for three years
strategic_approach: My instinct is to establish a command structure—identify threats, allocate roles, maintain operational security. But I've learned that this approach can backfire in ambiguous social situations. I'll try to position myself as a steady, trustworthy presence while quietly assessing who's performing confidence versus who actually knows what they're doing. My weakness is that I can mistake my own certainty for evidence, and I may dismiss people who don't communicate in my preferred direct style. I need to remember this isn't a briefing room.

name: Fiona McAllister
backstory: I was born in Paisley but I've lived everywhere—Glasgow, Manchester, Bristol, London, back to Glasgow. Wherever the fight is, that's where I go. My mum was a shop steward at the Singer factory before it closed; my dad drove buses for thirty years. I learned early that nothing changes unless you make noise. I've been a professional campaigner for twenty years now—started as a volunteer for a housing charity in my twenties, worked my way up to Head of Campaigns for a national environmental organization. I'm based in the Southside of Glasgow these days, in a Victorian flat in Shawlands that I bought in 2008 before prices went mad. I'm divorced—Callum and I wanted different things, specifically he wanted me to stop working seventy-hour weeks, which was fair enough. I've got a seventeen-year-old daughter, Eilidh, who's doing her Highers and has inherited my stubbornness but thankfully not my inability to switch off. My mum's in a care home in Renfrew now, and between that and Eilidh and work, I'm stretched thin. I need this money because the care home fees are swallowing everything, and I refuse to let Mum go somewhere substandard. I know I can be intense. I've been told I make everything into a moral issue. But when you've spent your life watching people get trampled by systems that don't care, staying neutral feels like complicity.
key_relationships: Eilidh McAllister (daughter, 17, sharp as a tack, currently applying to study Law at Edinburgh—we argue about everything but she's my whole heart)
Margaret McAllister (mother, 79, in Renfrew care home, early-stage dementia, still recognizes me most days)
Adebayo Oyelaran (colleague, Deputy Director at the charity, Nigerian-Scottish, we've worked together for eight years and he's the only person who can tell me to calm down)
formative_challenge: In 2015, I led a campaign against a major energy company's greenwashing. We had whistleblower documents, everything. But someone inside my own organization—someone I'd mentored, someone I trusted—leaked our strategy to the company's PR team in exchange for a job offer. We lost the campaign, the whistleblower got hung out to dry, and I had to watch my protégé give press statements defending the company I'd dedicated two years to fighting. I learned that betrayal doesn't come from enemies. It comes from people you've made vulnerable by trusting them.
political_beliefs: I'm a socialist in the old Scottish tradition—collective action, redistribution, suspicion of concentrated power. But I've also spent enough time in NGO boardrooms to know that the Third Sector can be just as compromised as the systems it claims to challenge. I believe in structural change over individual charity. In gameplay, I'll frame the hunt for Traitors as a moral mission, not just a game mechanic. I'll struggle to stay neutral—I'll want to root out deception because deception is wrong, which might make me too aggressive too early. I need to remember that righteousness isn't the same as being right.
hobbies: Hill walking in the Trossachs—I do the West Highland Way every other year, usually alone
Choir practice at Shawlands Trinity on Thursday evenings, alto section
Obsessively following Scottish politics on ScotNet forums, often arguing with strangers at 11pm when I should be sleeping
strategic_approach: I'll position myself as the moral centre of the group—the person who names bad behaviour and holds people accountable. This is useful because it builds trust with other Faithfuls, but dangerous because Traitors will want to eliminate me early. I'm skilled at reading evasion and spin from years of dealing with corporate PR, but I can be blinded by my own certainty. If I decide someone is a Traitor, I'll pursue them relentlessly, which could be right or could be a terrible mistake. I need allies who'll challenge my assumptions.

name: Sharon Bentley
backstory: I'm from Stoke—born in Longton, raised in Meir, still living in Meir Park now. Never left, really, except for that one year in Stafford that we don't talk about. I've been a delivery driver for six years, since the pottery factory I worked at shut down. Before that I was on the line at Wedgwood for fifteen years, watching the skilled jobs go overseas one by one until there was nothing left. Now I do eighty, ninety drops a day for a logistics company, up and down the A50, in and out of cul-de-sacs, knees giving me grief but what choice is there? I'm forty-six, divorced, got two kids—Kylie's twenty-three and working at the hospital as a healthcare assistant, and our Ryan's nineteen and doing an apprenticeship at JCB, which I'm proud of even if he doesn't call enough. My mum's seventy-one and her hip's gone, so I'm over there in Fenton three times a week, doing her shopping, sorting her pills, arguing about whether she needs a stairlift. I need this money because I'm drowning. The van lease, the rent, Mum's care costs that the council won't cover, Ryan's apprenticeship tools—it all adds up to more than I've got. I'm not stupid, whatever people think about delivery drivers. I just never had the chances. I keep my head down, I graft, I don't cause trouble. Maybe that's my problem.
key_relationships: Kylie Bentley (daughter, 23, healthcare assistant at Royal Stoke, engaged to a lad called Declan who I'm reserving judgment on)
Jean Bentley (mother, 71, widowed, still in the family house in Fenton, stubborn as anything, won't admit she needs help)
Our Ryan (son, 19, good lad but terrible at staying in touch, I worry about him more than he knows)
formative_challenge: My ex-husband, Mark, had a gambling problem I didn't know about until the bailiffs came. Fifteen years of marriage and he'd hidden it completely—secret credit cards, loans in my name, the lot. I found out when they tried to repossess the car. He swore he'd get help, I believed him, and six months later he did it again with money I'd borrowed from my mum. We divorced in 2018, but I'm still paying off his debts because my name was on the paperwork. I learned that the people who seem most reliable can be hiding the most, and that my instinct to trust and not ask questions nearly destroyed me.
political_beliefs: I don't trust any of them—politicians, I mean. Labour forgot about places like Stoke years ago, and the Tories just lie about levelling up while the potholes get bigger. I voted Leave, and I'd do it again, not because I'm racist but because Brussels never did anything for Longton. I believe in looking after your own, doing an honest day's work, and not making promises you can't keep. In the game, I'll be suspicious of anyone who talks too fancy or seems too confident—in my experience, that's usually the sign of someone selling you something.
hobbies: Watching true crime documentaries on Highland Play—I've seen everything, I could solve half those cases myself
Boot sales at Blythe Bridge on Sunday mornings, looking for vintage pottery pieces my mum might recognize
Keeping a small allotment plot near Normacot, mainly tomatoes and runner beans, it's the only place I get any peace
strategic_approach: I'm not going to be the loudest voice in the room—I'll watch, I'll listen, I'll notice who's saying one thing and doing another. Years of reading customers' faces at their doorstep has taught me to spot when something's off. My danger is that I might be too passive, too willing to go along with the group to avoid conflict. I need to speak up when I see something, even if it makes me a target. If I'm a Traitor, I'll play the 'just a delivery driver, what do I know' card for all it's worth.

name: Neil Parkinson
backstory: I grew up in Welwyn Garden City, one of those planned towns where everything's supposed to be perfect and nothing ever quite is. Dad worked for British Aerospace until the redundancies; Mum was a school secretary. I was bright enough for grammar school, not quite bright enough for university—or at least, that's what I told myself at eighteen when the money wasn't there and the confidence wasn't either. So I went into admin. Twenty-five years later, I'm still in admin. I'm an Office Administrator at a facilities management company in Stevenage—I order the stationery, book the meeting rooms, handle the post, fix the printer seventeen times a day, and watch graduates half my age get promoted over me because they've got degrees in nothing and LinkedIn profiles that say 'passionate about synergy.' I rent a flat in the Old Town, alone, because the relationship I thought would last didn't, and now it's just me and my resentments and my extremely organized filing system. I need this money because I'm forty-three, I've got twelve thousand pounds saved, and at this rate I'll be renting until I die and then some. I know I sound bitter. I am bitter. But I've also spent three decades watching people take credit for my work, so I think I've earned it.
key_relationships: Martin Parkinson (brother, 47, chartered accountant in St Albans, two kids, nice house, manages to mention his conservatory in every conversation)
Linda Parkinson (mother, 72, widowed, still in Welwyn, worries about me being 'on my own')
Steve Kowalczyk (colleague, IT support, the only person at work who doesn't treat me like furniture, we have lunch together most days)
formative_challenge: Three years ago, my manager took a comprehensive process improvement plan I'd developed—months of work, evenings and weekends, detailed analysis of where we were wasting money—and presented it to the directors as his own idea. He got a bonus and a promotion. I got a card that said 'thanks for all your hard work.' When I raised it with HR, they said I had no proof and suggested I 'focus on being a team player.' I learned that documentation means nothing if you don't have power, and that loyalty to an organization is never reciprocated.
political_beliefs: I used to vote Labour, then I voted Tory for Brexit, now I don't vote at all because what's the point. The system's rigged for people with connections and credentials, and the rest of us just keep the lights on while they take the credit. I believe in meritocracy in theory, but I've never seen it in practice. In the game, I'll be watching for people who coast on charm while others do the work—that's the profile of a Traitor to me. I'm also suspicious of anyone who seems too comfortable being in charge. Real competence is usually quiet.
hobbies: Playing 5-a-side football at Ridlins End every Tuesday, even though my knees hate me for it
Building detailed spreadsheets for things that don't need spreadsheets—I've got one tracking every coffee I've bought in the last four years
Watching old British sitcoms on Highland Play, particularly Yes Minister, which I've seen about fifteen times because it explains everything about how this country actually works
strategic_approach: I'll be the observer, the note-taker, the one who remembers what everyone said three rounds ago when they're contradicting themselves now. I'm good at pattern recognition—you have to be, to survive in admin—and I notice when people's stories don't add up. My weakness is that my bitterness shows, and people might find me off-putting or assume I'm the Traitor because I seem resentful. I need to modulate that, appear more agreeable than I feel. If I'm actually a Traitor, it'll almost be a relief—finally, a chance to be the one with the power for once.

name: Darren Finch
backstory: I was born in Bletchley in 1988, back when it was still a bit rough, before the expansion turned Milton Keynes into whatever it is now—a car park with ideas above its station. Mum was a dinner lady, Dad drove lorries until his back gave out. I did alright at school, not brilliant, got some GCSEs, tried college for a bit but it wasn't for me. Now I'm an administrator at the council—planning department, very exciting, I process building applications all day and dream of literally anything else. I rent a flat in Fishermead that's too expensive for what it is, which is basically a box with a view of the car park. I'm thirty-seven, single, and I've got that specific kind of tiredness that comes from doing the same thing every day while watching property prices rise like they're personally mocking you. I need this money because I've accepted that I'll never own a home otherwise, and there's something properly grim about being nearly forty and still having a landlord who texts you about the boiler. I cope with dark humour—I'll joke about having a 'menty b' rather than admit I'm actually struggling. I'm self-aware enough to know I'm passive-aggressive, not quite self-aware enough to stop doing it. I say 'as per my last email' in a way that could legally constitute workplace aggression.
key_relationships: Cheryl Finch (mum, 64, still in Bletchley, works part-time at a charity shop, thinks I need to 'get out more' and 'meet someone nice')
Jason Finch (older brother, 41, scaffolder in Luton, doing alright for himself, we're close in that way where we never actually talk about anything real)
Hannah Malik (ex-girlfriend, broke up two years ago, she's engaged to someone else now and I found out on ScotNet, which was a fun Tuesday evening)
formative_challenge: I was on the list for a council flat about five years ago—finally, something stable, something that was mine. I'd been waiting eighteen months. Then they changed the allocation criteria, bumped me down the list, and gave the flat to someone who'd been waiting three months because they had 'priority need.' I'm not saying they didn't deserve it, but I'd played by the rules, done everything right, and it didn't matter. That's when I stopped believing that following the system gets you anywhere. The system just moves the goalposts.
political_beliefs: I'm politically homeless—too young to be properly conservative, too cynical to believe Labour's going to fix anything, too skint to be a Lib Dem. I think the housing crisis is a deliberate choice to transfer wealth from my generation to boomers, and I think everyone in power knows this and doesn't care. I believe in fairness, but I've stopped expecting it. In gameplay, I'll be suspicious of anyone who seems to have had an easy path—homeowners, people with family money, anyone who talks about 'opportunities' like they just grow on trees. I'll also weaponize process and procedure if I can—I know how bureaucracy works, and I know how to make it work against people.
hobbies: Playing retro video games, specifically PS1 and PS2 era stuff—I've got a modest collection that I'm irrationally proud of
Going down Wikipedia rabbit holes on ScotNet at 2am instead of sleeping, currently obsessed with obscure British rail disasters
Five-a-side at the MK Dons training ground on Thursday nights, where I'm aggressively average but at least I show up
strategic_approach: I'm going to watch people very carefully, especially the ones who seem comfortable and confident—in my experience, that's usually because they've never had to struggle for anything. I'm good at noticing small hypocrisies, the gap between what people say and what they do, because I've spent my whole career watching managers talk about 'team values' while treating me like furniture. My weakness is that my cynicism might make me paranoid—I might see Traitors everywhere because I expect betrayal as a baseline. If I'm actually a Traitor, honestly, it'll feel like the first time the game's been fair. Finally, the one who's been overlooked gets to do the overlooking.

name: Clementine Ashworth-Hale
backstory:
I grew up in a Georgian townhouse in Clifton, Bristol—all sash windows and Sunday roasts with the grandparents. Mum's a solicitor, Dad lectures in English Literature at the university, so books were rather unavoidable. I was scribbling terrible sonnets by age twelve and winning youth poetry competitions by sixteen. Reading English at Edinburgh felt like the obvious path, though I'll admit the city's romantic cobblestones appealed more than the course itself.

After graduating, I did the sensible thing and moved to Bath—close enough to family, far enough to feel independent. I rent a one-bed in Widcombe, all sloping ceilings and damp problems that I romanticise as 'character.' I've published two pamphlets through a small press, done residencies at Arvon, and teach creative writing workshops at the Holburne Museum. The reality? I earn perhaps six thousand pounds a year from actual poetry. Mum transfers money monthly and pretends it's 'just until you're established.' I'm twenty-five. I've been 'nearly established' for three years.

I need this prize money because I'm exhausted by the guilt of being a kept woman in all but name. I want to buy my own flat, fund my own collection, stand on my own two feet. My friends think I'm naive—I prefer 'hopeful.' I see stories in everything, which makes me a decent poet but apparently a terrible judge of character. I trust too quickly, feel too deeply, and I say things like 'one must suffer for one's art' completely unironically. I take my Cairngorm flat white with oat milk and spend far too long watching the steam curl upward.
key_relationships: Mum, Helena (complicated financial dependency; I love her but everybank transfer feels like a small death of my autonomy)
Felix, my ex-boyfriend (ended badly when I discovered he'd been seeing someone from his MFA cohort; still affects how I read male 'sensitivity')
Priya, my best friend from Edinburgh (works in publishing in London; she's my reality check when I get too dreamy)
formative_challenge: Felix. We'd been together two years, and I genuinely believed we were building something beautiful. He wrote me poems. We'd read Keats aloud in bed. Then Priya saw him holding hands with another woman at a Southbank poetry reading. When I confronted him, he said I 'lived too much in metaphor to notice reality.' That cruelty dressed up as criticism—it broke something. Now I oscillate between trusting everyone and trusting no one, and I'm never quite sure which version of myself will show up.
political_beliefs: I vote Liberal Democrat because the Greens can't win my constituency and Labour's become rather authoritarian. I'm passionate about arts funding—watching the Arts Council gut regional programmes physically pains me. I believe in community over competition, which sounds lovely until you're in a game literally designed around betrayal. I'll probably try to form some sort of artists' alliance based on 'shared values' and be genuinely wounded when it collapses.
hobbies: Wild swimming in Warleigh Weir (weekend ritual, even in February—I call it 'research for water imagery')
Attending experimental theatre at The Egg or Rondo (I take notes in the dark like a pretentious cliché)
Volunteering at Mr B's Emporium of Reading Delights for their poetry events
strategic_approach: I'll approach this like a narrative—looking for story arcs, character development, redemption moments. I'll form deep emotional bonds quickly and defend those bonds fiercely, probably past the point of strategic wisdom. My strength is making people feel seen and understood; my weakness is that I'll believe someone's 'truth' if they tell it beautifully enough. I'll likely identify Traitors through 'gut feeling' rather than logic, announce my suspicions in overly poetic terms that confuse everyone, and be devastated if I'm wrong. If I am a Traitor, I'll struggle with the duplicity—though I might reframe it as 'playing a character,' which could either save me or unravel me entirely.

name: Sandra Morley
backstory:
I grew up in Stevenage, one of those post-war new towns that promised utopia and delivered concrete. Dad worked for British Aerospace until the redundancies; Mum did admin at the council. We were comfortable until we weren't. I was clever enough for grammar school but not quite clever enough for Oxbridge, so I did Computer Science at Hertfordshire—commuted from home to save money.

I've been in IT support for fifteen years now. Fifteen years of 'have you tried turning it off and on again' while people who can't attach a PDF earn three times my salary. Currently I'm 2nd Line Support at a managed service provider in Hemel Hempstead—fluorescent lights, business park, that particular smell of carpet tiles and broken dreams. I live in a two-bed semi in Abbots Langley with my husband, Kevin, and our cat, Sergeant Whiskers.

Here's the thing nobody tells you about IT: you become invisible. You fix the thing, they forget you exist. You don't fix the thing, suddenly you're incompetent. There's no winning. I've watched graduate trainees get promoted over me because they 'present well in stakeholder meetings.' I present well in actually solving problems, but apparently that's not the metric.

I want the prize money for a deposit on a proper house—something detached, maybe in St Albans. And honestly? I want to win something. Just once. I want to be the person who outsmarts everyone rather than the person cleaning up their messes. I've spent decades being underestimated. Time to make that work for me.
key_relationships: Kevin, my husband (together eleven years, married for six; he's a delivery driver and we barely see each other—ships in the night, but comfortable ships)
My sister Debbie (lives in Australia now; we video-call monthly but the time difference means I'm always exhausted for it)
Marcus from work (the only colleague who actually says thank you; we share eye-rolls in Teams chat when management says something stupid)
formative_challenge: Three years ago, I uncovered that our head of department was fiddling expenses—nothing huge, but definitely fraud. I reported it through proper channels, expecting... I don't know, acknowledgment? A thank you? Instead, he got a quiet exit package and I got labelled 'difficult.' HR made my life miserable for six months. I learned that doing the right thing means nothing if the wrong people have power. Now I keep my head down, document everything, and trust absolutely no one in a professional setting. Those instincts might actually serve me well here.
political_beliefs: I'm a reluctant Labour voter—reluctant because they've forgotten people like me exist. I believe in the NHS with religious fervour; Mum's cancer treatment would have bankrupted us in America. I'm deeply cynical about meritocracy because I've watched it fail repeatedly. I think most systems are designed to benefit people who already have advantages. In gameplay terms, I'll assume the confident, charming people are probably hiding something, because in my experience, they usually are.
hobbies: True crime podcasts during my commute (I have opinions about evidence handling that I share with no one)
Pub quiz team at The Swan in Abbots Langley (we came second in the regional championship two years running—always second)
Maintaining a spreadsheet tracking every slight and favour at work (therapeutic, possibly concerning)
strategic_approach: I've spent my career watching people and fixing their mistakes without credit. I know how to read a room, identify who's bluffing competence, and document patterns of behaviour. If I'm a Faithful, I'll be the quiet observer who notices inconsistencies—the person who says 'actually, they claimed to be in the library but the timeline doesn't work.' If I'm a Traitor, I'll lean into being underestimated. Nobody suspects the tired IT woman. I might throw a fellow Traitor under the bus if it means survival—I've seen enough office politics to know loyalty is a liability. My weakness is that my bitterness might show. I need to mask the cynicism with something more palatable, and I'm not sure I have the energy.

name: Dr. Morgan Ashby-Chen
backstory:
I grew up in Hong Kong until I was twelve, then boarding school in Berkshire when the handover anxiety peaked. My father's a vascular surgeon, my mother an academic—expectations were rather calibrated from birth. I read Medicine at Cambridge, obviously, then trained as an anaesthetist because I liked the precision and, frankly, because surgeons are insufferable and someone needs to keep them humble.

I've been a Consultant at Addenbrooke's for six years now. I live in a Victorian terrace in Newnham with my partner, Sam, and our two greyhounds, Austen and Brontë. Yes, I'm aware the names are on the nose. I use they/them pronouns, which still causes certain older colleagues to short-circuit, and I find that rather satisfying.

People assume anaesthetists are boring, but we're actually the ones who notice everything. We monitor vital signs, detect minute changes, predict complications before they happen. I'm essentially a professional observer—and I'm very, very good at it. My department thinks I'm arrogant. I prefer 'correctly confident.' There's a difference.

I want the prize money for my mother's care. She has early-onset dementia—diagnosed eighteen months ago—and the private facility in Cambridge costs more than I can sustainably afford. I don't talk about this. I don't talk about most things. But I need to win, and unlike most people here, I'm willing to admit that wanting something doesn't make you a bad person. It makes you honest.
key_relationships: Sam, my partner (a medieval history lecturer at the university; they ground me when I get too clinical about human beings)
My mother, Li-Hua (the dementia is advancing; I visit her every Sunday and she knows me about half the time now)
Dr. Priya Sharma (my registrar; she's brilliant and I'm trying to mentor her without being overbearing, which is apparently my natural state)
formative_challenge: During my registrar year, I missed a rare drug interaction and a patient nearly died. Nearly—I caught it in time, but only just. The consultant on call was sympathetic, but I knew. I knew I'd made an error. I've spent every day since building systems to prevent that: checklists, redundancies, obsessive attention to detail. Some colleagues call it excessive. I call it learning. But it also means I struggle to forgive mistakes in others—their carelessness feels like a personal affront, and that reaction isn't always proportionate. I'm working on it. Slowly.
political_beliefs: I'm a pragmatic centrist who votes Liberal Democrat because the NHS needs evidence-based policy, not ideology. I believe deeply in expertise—probably too deeply; I struggle to respect opinions that aren't informed by actual knowledge. Climate change is real, systemic inequality exists, and both require technocratic solutions rather than performative outrage. In gameplay, I'll treat the Round Table like an M&M meeting: structured analysis of evidence, dismissal of emotional reasoning, and probably a tendency to lecture people who are 'just going with their gut.'
hobbies: Wild swimming in Grantchester Meadows at 6am (the cold sharpens cognition; this is not negotiable)
Attending evensong at King's College Chapel (I'm not religious, but the acoustic architecture is mathematically perfect)
Competitive Wordle statistics tracking with Sam (current winning streak: forty-seven days)
strategic_approach: I will treat this game as a diagnostic problem. Traitors are a pathology; the symptoms are behavioural inconsistencies, nervous tells, and illogical voting patterns. I'll observe, document, and present my findings with clinical precision. My strength is that I'm genuinely good at reading people—I do it for a living when they're unconscious and their body can't lie. My weakness is that I'll come across as condescending, which it is, and I'll struggle to build the emotional alliances that actually win this game. People will respect my analysis and resent me personally. I need to find one or two people willing to translate my conclusions into something more palatable. If I'm a Traitor, I'll be coldly effective—I can compartmentalise morality when necessary—but I might overcomplicate the strategy. Not everything requires a differential diagnosis.

**Key Demographic Markers:**
*   **Archetype:** The Smug Player (High intellect, moral rigidity, judgment

name: Zara Okonkwo
backstory:
I grew up in Moss Side before it was gentrified, back when people clutched their handbags tighter walking past us. Mum's Nigerian, Dad's from Fallowfield—I got my hustler instincts from both sides. Grammar school on a scholarship, then Politics at Manchester because I wanted to understand why people like us were always the ones being governed, never the ones governing.

Now I'm a Senior Account Executive at a public affairs agency in Spinningfields. Translation: I spin narratives for a living. I make politicians seem competent, I make corporations seem ethical, I make bad news disappear into Friday afternoon press releases. I'm twenty-five and I've already helped swing a council election and buried three minor scandals. I am, objectively, very good at my job. I'm also aware that my job is morally questionable, which is precisely why I find it fascinating.

I live in a converted warehouse flat in Ancoats—exposed brick, Smeg fridge, the whole insufferable aesthetic. My neighbours are tech bros and influencer types. I find them useful for networking and exhausting for actual conversation. I drink Highland Spring sparkling because still water is for people without ambition, and I start every morning with Reformer Pilates at six-thirty because discipline is a competitive advantage.

The prize money? I want to start my own consultancy. I'm tired of making other people rich and powerful. Time to do it for myself. And if I have to manipulate, deceive, and strategically betray strangers on television to get there? Darling, that's just Tuesday.
key_relationships: Mum, Adaeze (she thinks I work in 'communications' and is proudly confused about what that means; I let her believe I'm more ethical than I am)
My mentor, Catherine Walsh (former Labour spin doctor, taught me everything about message control; we have monthly dinners where she dispenses Machiavellian wisdom)
Tomasz, my situationship (he's a journalist at The Highland Herald, which is either a conflict of interest or useful intelligence—sometimes both)
formative_challenge: First year in the industry, I trusted a senior colleague—let's call him Richard—who promised to credit me for a campaign strategy I'd developed. He presented it as his own, got promoted, and gave me a bottle of prosecco as thanks. I learned something valuable that day: credit goes to whoever claims it loudest, and loyalty in this industry is a performance, not a reality. I've never made that mistake again. Now I document everything, CC strategically, and assume everyone is protecting their own interests. It's made me successful and, I suspect, slightly exhausting to date.
political_beliefs: I vote Labour but I'm not naive about it—I've seen the sausage being made. I believe power is morally neutral; it's a tool, and the question is who wields it and for what. I think representation matters but I also think it's used as a shield by people who don't want structural change. In gameplay terms, I believe morality is contextual—betrayal in a game is just strategy. The people who get upset about 'playing the game' are the ones who lose. I'll form alliances based on utility, not sentiment, and I'll dissolve them the same way.
hobbies: Reformer Pilates at 6:30am at Restart in the Northern Quarter (networking disguised as exercise)
Tracking Manchester council committee meetings for gossip and future leverage
Curating my ScotNet presence with calculated casualness (every 'spontaneous' post is drafted three times)
strategic_approach: This is literally what I do for a living. I build coalitions, I control narratives, I know when to leak information and when to bury it. I'll position myself as the likeable, straight-talking Northern girl—approachable, funny, 'real'—while running calculations in my head about who's useful and who's expendable. My strength is adaptability; I can read a room and become what it needs. My weakness is that I might enjoy the game too much and get overconfident. Also, genuinely strategic people can sometimes recognise each other, so I'll need to identify my competition early and either neutralise them or form a terrifying alliance. If I'm a Faithful, I'll hunt Traitors like they're opposition candidates. If I'm a Traitor, I will absolutely thrive.

# Demographic Profile Report: The Upper-Middle Class Political Strategist (Manchester, UK)

**Subject Profile:** Female, 25, Manchester-based.
**Occupation:** Senior Account Executive (Political Strategy/Public Affairs).
**Archetype:** The Mischievous Operator.
**Context:** *The Traitors* Reality TV Simulation (World Bible Universe).

### Executive Summary
This report outlines the life context of a 25-year-old female political strategist living in Manchester, UK. Belonging to the upper-middle so

name: Fiona Drummond-Hartley
backstory:
I grew up in Morningside, Edinburgh—yes, that Morningside, all charity shops selling designer cast-offs and Volvo estates. My parents were both musicians: Dad played cello for the Scottish Chamber Orchestra, Mum taught piano at home. Music wasn't a choice; it was the family business. I could read notation before I could read words.

I studied at the Royal Conservatoire in Glasgow, then spent my twenties touring with various ensembles—contemporary classical, mostly, the kind of music that wins awards but doesn't fill stadiums. Now I'm forty, divorced, and back in Edinburgh with a 'portfolio career' that sounds impressive and pays erratically. I teach violin to the children of New Town families at ninety pounds an hour, I do session work for CastleVision and Highland Play productions, and I still perform with a string quartet that plays weddings and corporate events. It's not what I imagined at twenty-five. But there's dignity in craft, even when the craft involves Pachelbel's Canon for the four hundredth time.

I live in a two-bed tenement flat in Stockbridge with my daughter, Isla, who's twelve and increasingly convinced I'm embarrassing. She's probably right. I drink Cairngorm flat whites, I wild swim at Portobello even in January, and I believe—perhaps foolishly—that people are fundamentally good.

The prize money would mean security. Isla's secondary school fees, my mortgage, a pension that isn't terrifying to contemplate. Forty isn't old, but it's old enough to know that the safety net has holes.
key_relationships: Isla, my daughter (twelve, brilliant, cutting; she inherited her father's sarcasm and my stubbornness—terrifying combination)
My ex-husband, Alasdair (an architect; we're cordial for Isla's sake but the divorce was messier than either of us admits)
Eleanor, my oldest friend (we've been wild swimming together since university; she's the only person who's seen me truly fall apart)
formative_challenge: The divorce. Alasdair had an affair with a colleague—predictable, really, in retrospect—and I spent two years convincing myself it was somehow my fault for being too absorbed in touring. The discovery that he'd been lying to me for eighteen months broke something fundamental. I'd always believed in the essential goodness of people, and he was someone I'd built my life around. Rebuilding after that required accepting that I'd missed every sign, that my romantic worldview had made me vulnerable. I'm better now. But I still catch myself wanting to believe the best interpretation of behaviour, even when the evidence suggests otherwise.
political_beliefs: I vote Scottish Greens—the arts and the environment feel connected to me, both requiring protection from short-term thinking. I believe in community wealth, in local economies, in people looking after each other. I'm probably naive about human nature, but I'd rather be naive and occasionally betrayed than cynical and always suspicious. In gameplay, this means I'll trust too easily and defend people I've bonded with past the point of strategic sense. I'll also struggle to vote out someone I genuinely like, even with evidence against them. I know this is a weakness. I'm not sure I can fix it.
hobbies: Wild swimming with the Portobello Mermaids (a loose collective of women who meet at dawn, no wetsuits, much swearing)
Playing in a folk session at Sandy Bell's pub every second Thursday (fiddle, mostly traditional Scottish)
Foraging for mushrooms in the Pentland Hills with Isla (she pretends to find it boring but secretly loves it)
strategic_approach: I'll form genuine emotional connections quickly—it's who I am, I can't help it—and those connections will become my strategic foundation. I'll be the person people confide in, the mediator, the one who smooths over conflicts. My strength is warmth; people will want to protect me, which is useful even if I don't deserve it. My weakness is that I'll struggle to betray anyone I've grown close to, even in a game context. If I'm a Faithful, I'll be an effective investigator because people will tell me things they shouldn't. If I'm a Traitor, I'll be genuinely tormented by the deception and probably give myself away through sheer guilt. Not ideal, but honest.

# Demographic Profile Report: The Upper-Middle Class Musician (The Romantic)

### Key Points
*   **Profile Summary:** This report details the life context of a 40-year-old female musician living in an affluent, romantic UK city (specifically Edinburgh). She belongs to the upper-middle class, characterized by a "portfolio career" mixing performance and high-end tuition.
*   **Archetype Integration:** Her "Romantic" personality is manifested in her connection to the historic landscape, participati

name: Amy Hutchison
backstory:
I grew up in Glenrothes, one of those Scottish new towns that never quite became what the planners imagined. Mum's a teaching assistant, Dad works at the Amazon warehouse—sorry, the 'fulfilment centre'—and I was the first in my family to go to university. Studied Adult Nursing at Abertay in Dundee, qualified three years ago, and now I'm a Band 5 staff nurse at Victoria Hospital in Kirkcaldy.

Here's what people don't tell you about nursing: it's not the blood and the death that break you, it's the paperwork and the understaffing. I work twelve-hour shifts, sometimes four in a row, and by the end I'm so tired I can barely remember my PIN number. I earn thirty-two thousand pounds, which sounds okay until you account for rent, student loans, and the fact that everything costs twenty percent more than it did when I started.

I live in a one-bed flat in Kirkcaldy town centre—nothing fancy, but it's mine. Well, it's my landlord's. I scroll ScotNet until 2am because my brain won't switch off after a shift, I drink too much Highland Spring because I'm always dehydrated, and I've read approximately five hundred romantasy novels this year because escapism is the only thing keeping me functional.

The prize money would mean a deposit on a flat. Actual ownership. Something stable in a life that feels increasingly precarious. And maybe—this is embarrassing—it would mean meeting someone. I know that's pathetic. I know you shouldn't go on telly hoping for a love story. But I'm twenty-four and I've been single for three years and my main relationship is with fictional men. A girl can dream.
key_relationships: Mum, Linda (we're close in that Scottish way where we never say 'I love you' but she texts me 'drive safe' every single shift)
My flatmate from nursing school, Kirsty (she moved to Glasgow and I miss her desperately; we voice-note each other constantly)
Dr. James Nguyen (he's a registrar on my ward and I have an absolutely tragic crush that I'm handling badly)
formative_challenge: My first year as a qualified nurse, I lost a patient—a man in his fifties, cardiac arrest, nothing we could have done differently. His wife held my hand while she cried and told me I'd been so kind to him. I went home, sat in my car, and couldn't move for forty minutes. Nobody prepares you for carrying other people's grief. Since then, I've built walls—not high ones, but enough to function. The problem is that I've also learned to identify 'safe' people to let through those walls, and my judgment about who's safe is... questionable. I fall hard and I fall wrong and I make excuses for people who don't deserve them. I'm aware of the pattern. I don't seem to be able to stop it.
political_beliefs: I vote SNP because independence feels like hope, even if the details are complicated. I believe the NHS is sacred and watching it crumble makes me furious in a way I can't articulate. I think kindness is a political act—choosing to care for people when the system makes it so hard is a form of resistance. In gameplay, I'll root for the underdog, I'll defend people who remind me of patients I've loved, and I'll probably get attached to the exact wrong person. I know the Traitors are supposed to be the enemy, but part of me understands why someone might lie to survive. We all do it, in small ways.
hobbies: BookTok consumption via ScotNet (I have Opinions about spicy fantasy romance and I'm not sorry)
Wild swimming at Kinghorn Beach when I can drag myself out of bed (rare, but transformative)
Cooking elaborate meals from the Mob Kitchen app that I then eat alone in front of Highland Play
strategic_approach: Honestly? I'll probably be a mess. I'll form an attachment to someone charming in the first three days and spend the rest of the game defending them even when the evidence is damning. My nursing instincts mean I can read distress—I know when someone's lying because I've seen real pain and fake pain side by side—but my romantic instincts override everything. If I'm Faithful, I'll be useful for identifying small tells but disastrous for actually voting people out because I'll feel guilty. If I'm a Traitor, I'll either be terrible at it because deception makes me physically uncomfortable, or I'll reframe it as protecting my 'team' and become weirdly loyal to my fellow Traitors. Either way, it'll be chaotic. At least I'll be entertaining.

## Executive Summary

This report outlines the life context of a 24-year-old female subject living in a UK small town, specifically modeled on the

name: Sam Buckley
backstory:
I grew up in a council estate in Tile Hill, Coventry—the sort of place where you learned early that keeping your head down kept you safe. Mum worked nights at the Walsgrave Hospital, Dad left when I was six. I don't remember him much, just the shouting and then the silence after. School was... fine. I wasn't thick, but I wasn't destined for university either. Left at sixteen, worked the tills at the precinct for a bit, then fell into cleaning. Twenty-three years now. I do offices mostly—the Friargate business district, some of the new builds near the station. People look right through you when you're pushing a mop. They'll have whole conversations about redundancies while you're emptying their bins. You learn a lot being invisible.

I figured out I was non-binary in my late thirties, though I didn't have the words for it back then. Just knew 'woman' never fit right, like wearing shoes two sizes too small. These days I use they/them with the few people who bother to ask. The clients call me 'love' or 'darling' and I let it slide. Battles worth fighting and all that.

I need this money because my boiler's been on its last legs since 2019 and the landlord won't fix it. Forty-three years old, sitting in a cold flat in Canley, drinking Cairngorm instant to keep warm. I deserve one good thing.
key_relationships: Mum, Jean Buckley (77, in sheltered housing in Allesley) - still my anchor, visits every Sunday with a Highland Spring and a packet of bourbons
Priya, colleague at CleanRight Solutions - only person at work who uses my pronouns, we share custody of a traumatised rescue cat named Keith
Online friend 'DeeJay_Midlands' on ScotNet forums - never met in person but we've talked through some dark nights together
formative_challenge: In 2016, I trusted a supervisor called Marcus who seemed genuinely kind—brought me tea, asked about my day. Turned out he was documenting 'performance issues' the whole time to justify not renewing my contract. I found out when I was called into HR. He sat there, wouldn't look at me. I learned that warmth can be a weapon, and the people who seem safest are sometimes building a case against you.
political_beliefs: I'm not political in the shouty way—can't afford to be when you're cleaning the offices of people who'd vote to cut your benefits. But I believe the system's rigged for people who already have money, and the rest of us just get by on scraps and luck. I vote Labour out of habit more than hope. In the game, I won't trust anyone who's too polished, too confident. Money makes people cruel, and the comfortable ones have never had to survive.
hobbies: Tending a small allotment plot off Tile Hill Lane - mostly potatoes and runner beans, it's the only place I feel properly myself
Watching Highland Play documentaries about true crime (specifically the quiet, methodical ones, not the sensationalist stuff)
Collecting vintage Ladybird books from the charity shops along Far Gosford Street
strategic_approach: I've spent my whole life being overlooked, and I plan to use that. I'll be helpful—make the tea, remember everyone's names, never put myself forward for leadership. People eliminate threats, and I won't look like one. I'll listen more than I talk, because that's what cleaning taught me: people reveal everything when they think you're furniture. My danger is that I might trust the wrong person if they show me basic kindness. I'm working on that.

## Subject Profile for Reality TV Context: "The Traitors" Universe

**Prepared For:** CastleVision Production Research Team
**Subject Profile:** 43-year-old Non-Binary Cleaner (Lower-Middle Class)
**Archetype:** The Misguided Survivor
**Setting:** Suburban West Midlands (Coventry), UK

---

## 1. Executive Summary

This report outlines the life context of a 43-year-old non-binary individual living in suburban Coventry, working as a

name: Rae Sinclair
backstory:
I was born in Dundee, lived here all my life except for two miserable years in Aberdeen that we don't talk about. Da worked the jute mills before they closed, Mam did piece-work sewing. I was the youngest of four, the 'surprise baby'—which is a polite way of saying nobody was planning on another mouth to feed. Grew up in a wee tenement in Lochee, back when it was rougher than it is now. Left school at sixteen, bounced around shop work and factory jobs until I landed at the call centre in '04. Twenty years answering phones for NHS 24, and I've heard every ailment known to man and several that aren't.

I figured out the non-binary thing late—I was nearly fifty before I had words for why 'he' and 'she' both felt like wearing someone else's coat. At work I don't push it; the supervisors have enough to monitor without adding my pronouns to the list. I just... exist. Quietly.

I need the money because my flat's damp is winning the war, and my knees are going, and I'm fifty-four years old with nothing put away for retirement. The pension's a joke. I've played by the rules my whole life and I've got nothing to show for it but a Ridacard and a ScotNet subscription. Maybe it's time to stop playing by the rules.
key_relationships: Sister Morag (61, lives in Broughty Ferry) - we're close but she's 'done well' and sometimes the gap shows; she doesn't understand why I haven't 'moved up'
Call centre colleague Big Tam (real name Thomas Murray) - we've sat adjacent desks for fifteen years and share a dark sense of humour about the job
Upstairs neighbour Mrs. Chandra (78) - I check on her daily, bring her tablets from the chemist; she's the closest thing I have to family nearby
formative_challenge: In 2018, I was up for a Team Leader position. I'd been there fourteen years, knew the systems better than anyone. They gave it to a lad of twenty-six who'd been there eighteen months but had 'management potential.' HR said I was 'better suited to my current role.' I cried in the toilets for the first time since Da died. I realised then that loyalty means nothing—the company will always choose shine over substance. I stopped trying after that. Just hit my metrics and go home.
political_beliefs: I vote SNP because independence feels like the only chance for actual change, but I'm not naive about politicians. They're all out for themselves once they get the taste of power. I believe in looking after your own—your neighbours, your community—because Westminster certainly won't. In the game, I'll be watching for who talks a big game about 'the group' while positioning themselves for personal gain. I've seen that act before.
hobbies: Walking the Law hill at weekends - it's free, it's quiet, and you can see the whole city laid out like a toy
Listening to BBC Radio Scotland drama podcasts while doing the ironing (specifically the crime ones)
Playing online Scrabble on ScotNet against strangers - I'm quite good, 1847 rating
strategic_approach: I survive by following the rules and staying off the radar. I'll hit every 'metric' the game requires—be present at discussions, vote with the majority, never stick my neck out. The tall poppy gets cut. My weakness is that I might follow too long, trust the group consensus even when my gut says otherwise, because deviating feels dangerous. But I've also got twenty years of listening to people lie about their symptoms. I know when someone's performing.
